channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Under Armour and Steph Curry Launch Curry Brand
item.description: Zoom out: Even with Steph's marketing chops, Curry Brand alone probably won't be able to right Under Armour's ship. Nike's powerful Jordan Brand accounts for just ~9% of the company's overall revenue.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Facebook to Buy CRM Startup Kustomer for $1B+
item.description: Why Facebook wants in: Kustomer rounds out a growing suite of services Facebook offers to the millions of businesses that use its platforms.   buying promising startups and squashing competition. Over 175 million people chat up businesses on WhatsApp each day.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: GM Pulls out of Deal With Nikola Corporation
item.description: The nowstory: GM and Nikola are entering into a non-binding "potential agreement" that scraps the equity stake and Badger trucks.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Stocks, Crypto Post Record-Setting Month
item.description: Non-cryptocurrency: The dollar had its worst month since July, which is a sign investors stayed away from the safe haven asset and piled into riskier bets.   It's not totally surprising. Analysts point to greater commitments from big finance players—like PayPal and Square—for driving last month's 40% rally.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Biden Announces Economic Nominations and Appointments
item.description: Cecilia Rouse, dean of Princeton's School of Public and International Affairs, was nominated as chair.   Confirming recent reports, former Fed Chair Janet Yellen was nominated to become the first woman to head the Treasury.   Council of Economic Advisors: Think of it as the president's personal econ think tank, responsible for crafting policy and economic forecasting. Looking ahead…with a slowing recovery, worsening pandemic, and one month until ~12 million U.S. workers lose federal unemployment benefits, Biden's team will face the economic equivalent of Alabama in Week 1.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: GM Pulls out of Deal With Nikola Corporation
item.description: The nowstory: GM and Nikola are entering into a non-binding "potential agreement" that scraps the equity stake and Badger trucks.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Biden Announces Economic Nominations and Appointments
item.description: Cecilia Rouse, dean of Princeton's School of Public and International Affairs, was nominated as chair.   Confirming recent reports, former Fed Chair Janet Yellen was nominated to become the first woman to head the Treasury.   Council of Economic Advisors: Think of it as the president's personal econ think tank, responsible for crafting policy and economic forecasting. She'd be the first woman of color to head the OMB, but of all Biden's early nominees, she may face the tightest confirmation battle.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Facebook to Buy CRM Startup Kustomer for $1B+
item.description: Why Facebook wants in: Kustomer rounds out a growing suite of services Facebook offers to the millions of businesses that use its platforms.   buying promising startups and squashing competition. Over 175 million people chat up businesses on WhatsApp each day.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Under Armour and Steph Curry Launch Curry Brand
item.description: Zoom out: As effective as Steph is as a marketer, Curry Brand alone probably won't be able to right Under Armour's ship. Even Nike's powerful Jordan Brand accounts for just ~9% of the company's overall revenue.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: Stocks, Crypto Post Record-Setting Month
item.description: Small cap stocks, Wall Street verbiage for smaller companies that are publicly traded, had their best month ever—up 19%.     Non-cryptocurrency: The dollar had its worst month since July, which is a sign investors stayed away from the safe haven asset and piled into riskier bets.   It's not totally surprising.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The Week Ahead: November 30
item.description: Everything else:  Tuesday is the first day of December.    Earnings: Zoom will report Q3 financials today, Salesforce (following rumors it's in talks to acquire Slack) is up Tuesday, and recently IPOed Snowflake will report Wednesday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: EU, UK Have Just 1 Month Left to Make Brexit Deal
item.description: With just one month left to reach a deal protecting ~$1 trillion worth of trade between the EU and UK, this is shaping up to be a critical week for Brexit negotiations.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: NYC to Reopen Schools Next Week
item.description: Next week, NYC will begin reopening preschools, kindergartens, and elementary schools, with middle and high schools to follow later, Mayor Bill de Blasio's office announced yesterday.   Leaders everywhere are wrestling with this Without federal guidance, the decision to open schools falls on state and local officials.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Black Friday? More Like Cyber Friday.
item.description: Shopping on U.S. retail websites, however, rose 22% over last year to $9 billion, according to Adobe Analytics.   And today is Cyber Monday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Remembering Tony Hsieh, Former Zappos CEO
item.description: Hsieh took over and built an e-comm shoe colossus.   ShoeSite. Hsieh then started a fund and invested in the online shoe seller Zappos (then known as ShoeSite.   Quick bio In 1995, Hsieh (pronounced "shay") cofounded the internet ad company LinkExchange with a fellow Harvard alum. Nine years later...   more than $1 billion. At Zappos, he installed a self-management system called "Holacracy," which eliminated most traditional corporate hierarchy and allowed anyone to set meeting agendas.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: NYC to Reopen Schools Next Week
item.description: Next week, NYC will begin reopening preschools, kindergartens, and elementary schools, with middle and high schools to follow later, Mayor Bill de Blasio's office announced yesterday.   Leaders everywhere are wrestling with this Without federal guidance, the decision to open schools falls on state and local officials.

item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: The Week Ahead: November 30
item.description: Everything else:  Tuesday is the first day of December.    Earnings: Zoom will report Q3 financials today, Salesforce (following rumors it's in talks to acquire Slack) is up Tuesday, and 2020 hyped IPO Snowflake will report Wednesday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Remembering Tony Hsieh, Former Zappos CEO
item.description: Hsieh took over and built an e-comm shoe colossus.   ShoeSite. Hsieh then started a fund and invested in the online shoe seller Zappos (then known as ShoeSite.   Quick bio In 1995, Hsieh (pronounced "shay") cofounded the internet ad company LinkExchange with a fellow Harvard alum. Nine years later...   more than $1 billion. At Zappos, he installed a self-management system called "Holacracy," which eliminated most traditional corporate hierarchy and allowed anyone to set meeting agendas.

item.title: Black Friday? More Like Cyber Friday.
item.description: Shopping on U.S. retail websites, however, rose 22% over last year to $9 billion, according to Adobe Analytics.   And today is Cyber Monday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: A Rough Timeline of Covid-19 Immunization in the U.S.
item.description: January 31, 2021: About 50 million Americans could be vaccinated by now, and, grouped in with those who've recovered from Covid-19, over 30% of the population would be immune, per the dean of Brown's public health school, Ashish Jha. February/March: At 30%–40% immunity, according to Jha, the spread will become "meaningfully slower" and infections won't be "self-sustaining."
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Photos of Vaccination Throughout History
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Vaccination in the Workplace: Employers Advised to "Strongly Encourage"
item.description: Labor and employment attorney Michael Roche told Business Insider that the safest legal tack is for companies to "strongly encourage employees to get vaccinated." But can employers legally require their workers to get vaccines?
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Americans Are Divided Over The Covid-19 Vaccine
item.description: Establishing public trust in these vaccines will be the next major challenge for health officials. That's down from a peak of 50% in September, but remains a concerning number for public health officials who want to get Covid-19 under control.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: WHO Covax Initiative Seeks Equitable Access to Covid Vaccines
item.description: So far, Covax has secured 700 million doses and $2 billion in funding. The goal is to raise $5 billion and provide 2 billion doses by the end of 2021.   Big picture: The Duke Global Health Institute thinks it'll take until 2024 for vaccines to reach the entire population.  The Duke Global Health Institute estimates 9.6 billion doses are already reserved by individual countries, without any vaccines having reached the market yet.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Who Gets a Vaccine First?
item.description: The U.S.' ~20 million healthcare workers, including doctors, nurses, and support staff, will likely be top priority. #3: Not everyone will get a vaccine.     Who's first? But in 2009, researchers published a study suggesting a focus on vaccinating the biggest spreaders—in the case of swine flu, children ages 5–19—to protect everyone else. Reality check: There won't be enough Covid-19 vaccines for everyone for a while. In the last decade, the U.S. has never vaccinated more than half of adults for the flu, and vaccination rates for Black, Latinx, and high-risk adults trend lower. Other factors to consider #1: Different vaccines have different logistical challenges and health considerations, which could affect who gets what when.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: McKesson Will Be the Central Distributor of Covid-19 Vaccines
item.description: The company will not make decisions on where to send the vaccines, however.   Put me in, coach Through Operation Warp Speed, the government has made McKesson the central distributor of Covid-19 vaccines (outside of Pfizer-BioNTech’s, which needs to live in sub-Arctic temps).     Because of McKesson’s expertise in schlepping life-saving material, the country has tapped it for similar programs before. It’s a lucrative business.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Covid-19 Vaccine Distribution Effort: By the Numbers
item.description: $21—the difference in price between Moderna’s vaccine ($25/dose) and AstraZeneca’s vaccine ($4/dose), according to U.S. purchase agreements.   10 billion single doses could be available by the end of 2022 if all the frontrunner vaccine candidates are approved.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: How Temperature-Sensitive Vaccine Candidates Will be Distributed Via the Cold Chain
item.description: Dry ice is the cold chain’s best friend. Pfizer has designed temperature-controlled dry ice boxes that can maintain a roughly -94° Fahrenheit temperature for up to 10 days.   Bottom line: Even with distributors and drug companies beefing up their cold chain capacity, pharma experts still expect a spoilage rate between 5% and 20%.   Storage is tight.
item.author: Toby Howell

item.title: A Quick Teardown of Operation Warp Speed
item.description: Looking ahead...   Budget: Up to $18 billion.   The goal: To deliver 300 million doses of a safe and effective vaccine by Jan. 2021. OWS leadership has said they can deliver a Covid-19 vaccine to every state less than 24 hours after FDA approval.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Vaccine Manufacturing 101: The Brew Breaks it Down
item.description: Vaccine manufacturing is Isla de Muerta  It’s an island that cannot be found, except by those who already know where it is.   Plus, it’s not cheap. The total costs of vaccine development can run up to $500 million, one study found.   Regulators license the process behind making a vaccine in addition to the biological product itself.   Step 5: Distribution—mix up all the components in vials or syringes, load those suckers on trucks, and get them in some arms.   Step 3: Next, the antigen is purified through processes that sound like words you’d make up when lying about doing science homework: chromatography and ultrafiltration. Probably not, but Pfizer does. Basil’s gotta become pesto at some point.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: One Vaccine Dose’s Journey From Lab to Arm
item.description: But not so fast: Moderna’s vaccine requires two doses 28 days apart. The vaccine will fly in those Elsa-approved containers to a McKesson distribution facility in Irving, TX. We just spit a lot of information at you about the vaccine supply chain.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Photos of Vaccination Throughout History
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: 2021 Grammys: Recording Academy Announces Nominees
item.description: .   Looking ahead...   The snubs: The Academy still thinks of The Weeknd as Saturday and Sunday, even though the pop star will perform at the Super Bowl. Producer and Recording Academy chairman Harvey Mason Jr. said the artists will be present and there will be a small audience.
item.author: Eliza Carter

item.title: Gap, Nordstrom, Dick’s and More Report Earnings
item.description: Dick’s e-commerce sales rose 95%, while same-store sales grew 23%.   And Best Buy shares fell 7% when the company warned early holiday sales could mean lower demand ahead.   Abercrombie reported a 43% uptick in online sales.
item.author: Alex Hickey
